ygData.subject: Re: Speciation and Genome Clusters in the Encoding Space
ygData.msgSnippet: Oops, looks like Joel and I wrote the same clarification on novelty search at the same time :)  Oh well, Joel s is more informative than what I wrote. ken

Oops, looks like Joel and I wrote the same clarification on novelty
search =
at the same time :)  Oh well, Joel's is more informative than
what I wrote.=


ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "joel278" <lehman.154@...> wrote:
>
> H=
ey Colin,
> 
> You have some interesting ideas for refining speciation. I w=
onder what 
> sort of performance impact these changes might have.
> 
> I w=
anted to clarify your last remark about novelty search. The 
> algorithm yo=
u suggest does have certain surface similarities to 
> novelty search. 
> 
=
> The idea of avoiding previously explored areas of search space is not 
> =
new, and is known as tabu search. The combination of this with 
> speciatio=
n may allow for more efficient search by avoiding previously 
> explored ar=
eas of search space while promoting genotypic diversity. As 
> I understand=
 it, this is what you were suggesting. Feel free to 
> correct me if I have=
 misrepresented your idea.
> 
> Novelty search also uses a tabu-search like=
 approach to bias search, 
> although it operates in behavior space (phenot=
ype, behavior within a 
> domain) as opposed to search space (genotype). Th=
is in itself is not 
> original, as there exists previous work that used be=
havior-based 
> speciation with NEAT.
> 
> The main contribution of novelty=
 search is to demonstrate that in 
> deceptive domains searching only for n=
ovel behaviors (i.e. completely 
> ignoring any measure of fitness) can be =
more effective than a method 
> that uses a measure of fitness to bias sear=
ch. This is a surprising 
> result because nearly all practical search meth=
ods rely on measuring 
> progress towards a goal. While in deceptive domain=
s fitness may be led 
> into cul-de-sacs in search space (local optima), no=
velty search cannot 
> be deceived in the same way since it is not looking =
for anything other 
> than different ways to behave.
> 
> I do agree that t=
he archive in novelty search may be similar in 
> philosophy to your idea o=
f a FIFO list of dead species that guide 
> search away from explored areas=
 of search space. That is, both methods 
> keep a historical record of prev=
ious individuals and use that record 
> to encourage search to progress in =
alternate directions.  However, I 
> would say that the archive is not the =
defining feature of novelty 
> search. 
> 
> Anyways, I think your ideas fo=
r further exploration into speciation 
> are promising, and would be intere=
sted in seeing their effect on hard 
> problems. I am looking forward to se=
eing version 2 of sharpneat.
> 
> Joel
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "C=
olin Green" <colin.green1@> wrote:
> >
> > Here are some thoughts on specia=
tion that probably don't warrant a
> > deep discussion but I post them for =
the record.
> > 
> > Currently sharpneat takes a casual approach to speciat=
ion and I'm
> > wondering if there are improvements to be had. This ties in=
 with my
> > recent post about genome compatibilty metrics and 
> euclidean=
/manhattan
> > distance.
> > 
> > In sharpneat v2 I'm trying to make the co=
de base more abstract and
> > re-usable, e.g. I'm separating the NeatGenome=
 and EvolutionAlgorithm
> > classes from being dependent on each other and =
also using generics 
> so
> > that we can plug in new genomes or algorithms=
 with minimum effort.
> > Thus my previous discussion resulted in my creati=
ng an
> > ICompatibilityMetric<TGenome> interface which can be plugged in t=
o 
> the
> > NeatEvolutionAlgorithm.
> > 
> > Looking at speciation again I=
 see that at the outset I simply assign
> > genomes to species if they are =
within some distance and if not then 
> I
> > place the new genome in its o=
wn species. Independent of this I also
> > adjust the compatibility thresho=
ld once per generation in an attempt
> > to keep the species count between =
some limits (which has its own
> > problems and is another email in the mak=
ing). A possible problem 
> with
> > this approach is that the first attemp=
t at speciation will probably
> > just assign the first N genomes in the po=
pulation as being the first
> > genome in each species - these genomes then=
 become [temporary]
> > exemplars for the species, that is, the remaining g=
enomes are 
> compared
> > against them and if they are close enough to an =
exemplar they are
> > assigned to that species.
> > 
> > As an alternative =
approach I was thinking of taking the discussion
> > about compatibility (o=
r distance) metrics a step further and 
> actually
> > explicitly represent=
ing where genomes are in the encoding space with
> > something like an IEnc=
odingSpace interface, the idea being that I 
> take
> > the total number of=
 unique connection IDs in the whole population as
> > being the number of s=
pacial dimensions, I then define the location 
> of
> > each genome in each=
 dimension as being the connection weight for 
> that
> > ID (using 0 if a =
genome doesn't have a connection for agiven ID). 
> From
> > here I can fin=
d the range/limits of locations (weights) in each
> > dimension, which effe=
ctively defines an enclosing hypercube that the
> > current population is i=
nside. I can now divide up the hypercube into
> > equally sized sub-cubes i=
n order to find clusters of genomes that 
> are
> > close together and use =
this as the basis of my initial set of 
> species.
> > 
> > In addition to =
all that I suspect it makes sense to keep the 
> exemplar
> > for each spec=
ies consistent throughout the life of the species - so 
> a
> > genome (rep=
resenting a point in space) we keep to one side, that may
> > have been rem=
oved from the population long ago. This keeps each
> > species 'anchored' i=
n space and prevents it from drifting. We then
> > have the choice of keepi=
ng a FIFO buffer of dead species as an
> > indicator of parts of the search=
 space that have recently been
> > searched - avoiding these spaces when cr=
eating new genomes. This is 
> an
> > idea I raised a few years ago and whi=
ch I think is known as novelty
> > search.
> > 
> > Colin.
> >
>
